revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox military unit | unit_name = Kent Yeomanry | image = | caption = | dates = 20 August 1920 – 1 May 1961 | country = {{flag|United Kingdom}} | allegiance = | branch = [[Image:Flag of the British Army.svg|23px]] [[British Army]] | type = [[Field Artillery]]
[[Anti-aircraft artillery|Light Anti-Aircraft Artillery]] | role = | size = One Regiment
Two Regiments (Second World War) | command_structure = | garrison =[[Maidstone]] | garrison_label = Peacetime HQ | nickname = | patron = | motto = | colors = | colors_label = | march = | mascot = | equipment = | equipment_label = | battles = [[Second World War]] :{{nowrap|[[North-West Europe 1940]], [[North-West Europe 1944–45|'44–45]]}} :[[North Africa 1942–43]] :[[Italy 1944–45]] | anniversaries = | decorations = | battle_honours = | battle_honours_label = | disbanded = | flying_hours = | website = | commander1 = | commander1_label = | commander2 = | commander2_label = | commander3 = | commander3_label = | commander4 = | commander4_label = | commander5 = | commander5_label = | commander6 = | commander6_label = | commander7 = | commander7_label = | commander8 = | commander8_label = | commander9 = | commander9_label = | notable_commanders = | identification_symbol = | identification_symbol_label = | identification_symbol_2 = | identification_symbol_2_label = | identification_symbol_3 = | identification_symbol_3_label = | identification_symbol_4 = | identification_symbol_4_label = | aircraft_attack = | aircraft_bomber = | aircraft_electronic = | aircraft_fighter = | aircraft_helicopter = | aircraft_helicopter_attack = | aircraft_helicopter_cargo = | aircraft_helicopter_multirole = | aircraft_helicopter_observation = | aircraft_helicopter_transport = | aircraft_helicopter_trainer = | aircraft_helicopter_utility = | aircraft_interceptor = | aircraft_patrol = | aircraft_recon = | aircraft_trainer = | aircraft_transport = | aircraft_tanker = | aircraft_general = }} The '''Kent Yeomanry''' was an [[artillery]] [[regiment]] of the [[Territorial Army (United Kingdom)|Territorial Army]] formed in 1920 by the amalgamation of the [[Royal East Kent Yeomanry|Royal East Kent (The Duke of Connaught's Own) Yeomanry (Mounted Rifles)]] and [[Queen's Own West Kent Yeomanry|West Kent Yeomanry (Queen's Own)]]. For the [[Second World War]] it was expanded to form two [[field artillery]] regiments – '''97th (Kent Yeomanry) Field Regiment, Royal Artillery''' and '''143rd (Kent Yeomanry) Field Regiment, Royal Artillery''' – which saw active service in [[North African Campaign|North Africa]], [[Italian Campaign (World War II)|Italy]] and North-West Europe, both with the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War II)|BEF]] in [[Battle of France|1940]] and on the [[Second Front]] in 1944–45. Post war it was reconstituted as '''297th (Kent Yeomanry) Light Anti-Aircraft Regiment, Royal Artillery''' before being amalgamated in 1961 with the [[3rd/4th County of London Yeomanry (Sharpshooters)]] to form the [[Kent and Sharpshooters Yeomanry]]. ==History== ==={{anchor|6RFA|97RFA}}Formation=== Following the experience of the [[First World War]], it was decided that only the fourteen most senior [[yeomanry]] [[regiment]]s would be retained as horsed cavalry,{{harvnb|Mileham|1994|p=48}} with the rest being transferred to other roles.{{harvnb|Mileham|1994|p=50}} As a result, on 20 August 1920, the [[Royal East Kent Yeomanry|Royal East Kent (The Duke of Connaught's Own) Yeomanry (Mounted Rifles)]]{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715140005/http://regiments.org/regiments/uk/volmil-england/vcav/kentE.htm |date=15 July 2007 |title=Royal East Kent Yeomanry (The Duke of Connaught's Own) (Mounted Rifles) at regiments.org by T.F.Mills }} was amalgamated with the [[Queen's Own West Kent Yeomanry|West Kent Yeomanry (Queen's Own)]]{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715140005/http://regiments.org/regiments/uk/volmil-england/vcav/kentW.htm |date=15 July 2007 |title=West Kent Yeomanry (Queen's Own) at regiments.org by T.F.Mills }} to form the Kent Yeomanry and simultaneously re-roled as [[field artillery]] to form ''6th (Kent) Army Brigade, [[Royal Field Artillery|RFA]]''.{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715140005/http://regiments.org/regiments/uk/volmil-england/vcav/kentYeo.htm |date=15 July 2007 |title=Kent Yeomanry at regiments.org by T.F.Mills }} In 1921 the regiment regained its yeomanry title and was renumbered as the ''97th (Kent Yeomanry) Brigade, Royal Field Artillery''. Within the brigade, two [[Artillery battery|batteries]] were subtitled "Duke of Connaught's Own Yeomanry"{{snd}}385th at [[Canterbury]] and 386th at [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]]{{snd}}and two were subtitled "Queen's Own Yeomanry"{{snd}}387th at [[Bromley]] and 388th at [[Maidstone]]. The regiment's [[Headquarters#Military|HQ]] was also at Maidstone. Another title change came in June 1924 as the [[Royal Field Artillery]] was reamalgamated back into the [[Royal Artillery]] and the regiment became ''97th (Kent Yeomanry) Field Brigade, RA''. The final change came in 1938 as artillery [[brigades#United Kingdom|brigades]] became regiments, and the unit became ''97th (Kent Yeomanry) Army Field Regiment, RA'' in November.{{harvnb|Frederick|1984|pp=34–35}} By 1939 it became clear that a new European war was likely to break out, and the doubling of the Territorial Army was authorised, with each unit forming a duplicate.{{cite web | url=http://www.army.mod.uk/reserve/31793.aspx | title=History of the Army Reserve | publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|MOD]] | accessdate=2 April 2014}} 97th (Kent Yeomanry) Army Field Regiment, RA formed 143rd Field Regiment, RA. The new regiment continued the tradition of including batteries from both East and West Kent.{{harvnb|Mileham|1994|p=91}} ===Second World War=== ===={{anchor|97th Field Regiment, Royal Artillery}} 97th (Kent Yeomanry) Field Regiment, Royal Artillery==== 97th (Kent Yeomanry) Army Field Regiment mobilized on 3 September 1939 at Maidstone under [[Eastern Command (United Kingdom)|Eastern Command]] with 385th (Duke of Connaught's Own Yeomanry) and 387th (Queen's Own Yeomanry) Batteries.{{cite web | url=http://www.ra39-45.pwp.blueyonder.co.uk/field/page97.html | title=97 (Kent Yeomanry) Field Regiment RA(TA) | publisher=The Royal Artillery 1939-45 | first=Derek | last=Barton | accessdate=6 May 2014}} The regiment joined the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War II)|BEF]] in May 1940, initially with [[III Corps (United Kingdom)|III Corps]] then with the [[5th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|5th Infantry Division]].{{harvnb|Joslen|1990|p=47}} During the [[Battle of France]], the regiment saw action at [[Saint-Valery-en-Caux]] in June 1940; after the German advance the regiment destroyed its guns and equipment and headed to [[Dunkirk]] for evacuation in [[Operation Dynamo]].{{cite web | url=http://www.kentfallen.com/PDF%20REPORTS/97th%20KENT%20YEOMANRY%20R.A.pdf | title=97th (Kent Yeomanry) Field Regiment Royal Artillery | accessdate=7 May 2014 | publisher=Kent War Memorials Transcription Project | first1=David W | last1=Hughes | first2=Neil R | last2=Clark | first3=Kyle D | last3=Tallett}} Field regiments had been organised in 1938 into two 12-gun batteries. The experience of the BEF in 1940 showed the problem with this organisation: field regiments were intended to support an infantry brigade of three battalions. This could not be managed without severe disruption to the regiment. As a result, field regiments were reorganised into three 8-gun batteries.{{harvnb|Forty|1998|p=73}} The third battery (470th) was formed in the regiment at [[Great Baddow]] in March 1941.{{harvnb|Frederick|1984|p=525}} The regiment arrived in [[Iraq]] on 20 October 1941 and was initially under command of [[Tenth Army (United Kingdom)|Tenth Army]] before being assigned to [[10th Indian Infantry Division]] on 19 November. On 25 April 1942, 470th Battery left to form part of X (later 164th) Field Regt, RA. The rest of the regiment arrived in [[Egypt]] with the division on 31 May. On 5 July it came under command of [[British Troops in Egypt]].{{harvnb|Joslen|1990|p=505}} The regiment dropped the "Army" designation on 13 September and on the same date joined the [[7th Armoured Division (United Kingdom)|7th Armoured Division]].{{harvnb|Joslen|1990|p=19}} Armed with sixteen [[25 pounder]]s,{{harvnb|Joslen|1990|p=569}} the regiment served with 7th Armoured in the [[Second Battle of El Alamein]].{{harvnb|Joslen|1990|p=21}} On 20 December it was placed under command of GHQ, [[Middle East Command|Middle East Forces]]{{harvnb|Joslen|1990|p=483}} and 470th Battery was reformed for the regiment. In October 1943 it rejoined the 10th Indian Division,{{efn|Kempton does not support this assertion{{harvnb|Kempton|2003a|pp=65–73}} and Joslen states that the regiment ceased to be under command of Indian Formations on 5 July 1942.}} serving in North Africa, [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] and [[Italy]], where it ended the war on the Adriatic coast near [[Trieste]].{{harvnb|Bellis|1995|p=96}} The Regimental HQ with 385th, 387th and 470th Batteries were placed in suspended animation{{efn|name=SA|"suspended animation" describes units that continued to exist but without personnel or equipment.{{harvnb|Bellis|1994|p=8}}}} on 15 December 1945. ===={{anchor|143rd Field Regiment, Royal Artillery}} 143rd (Kent Yeomanry) Field Regiment, Royal Artillery==== 143rd Field Regiment mobilized on 3 September 1939 at Ashford under [[Eastern Command (United Kingdom)|Eastern Command]] with 386th (Duke of Connaught's Own Yeomanry) and 388th (Queen's Own Yeomanry) Batteries.{{cite web | url=http://www.ra39-45.pwp.blueyonder.co.uk/field/page143.html | title=143 (Kent Yeomanry) Field Regiment RA(TA) | publisher=The Royal Artillery 1939-45 | first=Derek | last=Barton | accessdate=6 May 2014}} It spent the early part of the war in [[Iceland in World War II|Iceland]]. While there, it was reorganised from two 12-gun batteries to three 8-gun batteries when the third battery (507th) was formed in the regiment in May 1941. It was authorised to use the "Kent Yeomanry" designation from 17 February 1942.{{harvnb|Frederick|1984|p=533}} Arriving back in the UK, the regiment was assigned to the [[49th (West Riding) Infantry Division]], ''the Polar Bears'', on 26 April 1942; it was to remain with the division for the rest of the war.{{harvnb|Joslen|1990|p=79}}{{harvnb|Bellis|1995|p=102}} The division began landing in [[Invasion of Normandy|Normandy]] on 12 June 1944 ([[Normandy landings|D-Day]]) + 6){{harvnb|Joslen|1990|p=80}} and participated in the [[North-West Europe Campaign of 1944–1945|North-West Europe Campaign]]. The regiment gave support to the British and Canadian forces attacking [[Battle for Caen|Caen]] ([[Operation Martlet|First]] and [[Second Battle of the Odon]]). They were also in action around [[Le Havre]] as part of the [[First Canadian Army]], at the [[Turnhout Canal]] and in the [[Battle of the Scheldt]]. The winter of 1944-1945 was spent on the Dutch - German border along the River [[Meuse River|Maas]]. Their final action was at [[Liberation of Arnhem|Second Battle of Arnhem]] in April 1945. The Regiment was placed in suspended animation after the war {{efn|name=SA}} on 18 April 1946 and was disbanded on 1 January 1947. ==={{anchor|297th (Kent Yeomanry) Light Anti-Aircraft Regiment}}Post war=== The Kent Yeomanry was reconstituted in the [[Territorial Army (United Kingdom)|Territorial Army]] on 1 January 1947 as '''297th (Kent Yeomanry) Light Anti-Aircraft Regiment, RA'''. HQ remained at Maidstone. On 1 May 1961, the regiment was amalgamated with [[3rd/4th County of London Yeomanry (Sharpshooters)]]{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715140005/http://regiments.org/regiments/uk/volmil-london/vcav/LonCo3-4.htm |date=15 July 2007 |title=3rd/4th County of London Yeomanry (Sharpshooters) at regiments.org by T.F.Mills }} to form [[Kent and County of London Yeomanry (Sharpshooters)]].{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715140005/http://regiments.org/regiments/uk/volmil-england/vcav/kentKSY.htm |date=15 July 2007 |title=Kent and Sharpshooters Yeomanry at regiments.org by T.F.Mills }} ==Battle Honours== The Kent Yeomanry was the custodian of the [[battle honour]]s of The Royal East Kent Mounted Rifles (The Duke of Connaught's Own) and The West Kent Yeomanry (Queen's Own).{{efn|These were: ;Second Boer War [[South Africa 1900–01]] ;First World War [[Second Battle of the Somme (1918)|Somme 1918]], [[Bapaume 1918]], [[Hindenburg Line]], [[Battle of Épehy|Épehy]], [[Hundred Days Offensive|Pursuit to Mons]], [[France and Flanders 1918]], [[Gallipoli 1915]], [[Egypt 1916–17]], [[Gaza (Battle honour)|Gaza]], [[Battle of Jerusalem (1917)|Jerusalem]], [[Battle of Tell 'Asur|Tell 'Asur]], [[Palestine 1917–18]]}} ;Second World War The Royal Artillery was present in nearly all battles and would have earned most of the honours awarded to cavalry and infantry regiments. In 1833, [[William IV of the United Kingdom|William IV]] awarded the motto ''Ubique'' (meaning "everywhere") in place of all battle honours.{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715140005/http://regiments.org/regiments/uk/art-eng-sig/RA.htm |date=15 July 2007 |title=Royal Regiment of Artillery at regiments.org by T.F.Mills }} ==See also== {{portal|British Army|World War II}} * [[Yeomanry]] * [[List of British Army Yeomanry Regiments converted to Royal Artillery]] * [[Kent and Sharpshooters Yeomanry]] * [[Royal Yeomanry]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite book | ref = harv | last = Bellis | first = Malcolm A. | year = 1995 | title = Regiments of the British Army 1939–1945 (Artillery) | publisher = Military Press International | location = London | isbn = 0-85420-110-6 }} * {{cite book | ref = harv | last = Forty | first = George | year = 1998 | title = British Army Handbook 1939–1945 | publisher = Sutton Publishing Limited | location = Stroud, Gloucestershire | isbn = 0-7509-1403-3 }} * {{cite book | ref = harv | last = Frederick | first = J.B.M. | year = 1984 | title = Lineage Book of British Land Forces 1660–1978 | publisher = Microform Academic Publishers | location = Wakefield, Yorkshire | isbn = 1-85117-009-X }} * {{cite book | ref = harv | last = Joslen | first = Lt-Col H.F. | year = 1990 | origyear = 1st. Pub. [[HMSO]]:1960 | title = Orders of Battle, Second World War, 1939–1945 | publisher = London Stamp Exchange | location = London | isbn = 0-948130-03-2 }} * {{cite book | ref = harv | last = Kempton | first = Chris | year = 2003 | title = 'Loyalty & Honour', The Indian Army September 1939 – August 1947 | volume = Part I Divisions | publisher = The Military Press | location = Milton Keynes | isbn = 0-85420-228-5 }} * {{cite book | ref = harv | last = Mileham | first = Patrick | year = 1994 | title = The Yeomanry Regiments; 200 Years of Tradition | publisher = Canongate Academic | location = Edinburgh | isbn = 1-898410-36-4 }} ==External links== * {{oob unit | id = 3818 | name = 97 Field Regiment RA }} * {{oob unit | id = 7762 | name = 143 Field Regiment RA }} [[Category:Military units and formations in Kent]] [[Category:Yeomanry regiments of the British Army]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1920]] [[Category:Military units and formations disestablished in 1961]] [[Category:Regiments of the British Army in World War II]] [[Category:1920 establishments in the United Kingdom]]
